# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Data

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
audi_filter(df_cars)

Here is a solution in Julia using the DataFrames.jl package:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter rows with manufacturer as "audi" and model as "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df = filter(row -> row[:manufacturer] == "audi" && (row[:model] == "a4" || row[:model] == "a4 quattro"), df)
    
    # Add a new column "audi_a4_type" with all values equal to true
    df[:audi_a4_type] = fill(true, nrow(df)) 
    
    return df
end
```
You can then call this function using your data:

```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "audi", "bmw", "audi", "audi", "ford", "audi", "audi", "toyota", "audi"],
    model=["a4", "a6", "3 series", "a4 quattro", "q7", "fusion", "tt", "a4", "corolla", "a4 quattro"])
df_result = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
This solution assumes that the input DataFrame already has column names `manufacturer` and `model`. If these are different, you'll need to adjust this code accordingly.
